mn94:1.1.comm: As usual, the lack of mention of the Buddha at the start suggests that this sutta is set after his passing away, a detail confirmed at the end. This sutta attests to the continued influence of Buddhism among the wealthy and influential as they adapted to the new realities after the Buddha’s passing.

mn94:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā udeno bārāṇasiyaṃ viharati khemiyambavane.
mn94:1.2.eng: At one time Venerable Udena was staying near Varanasi in the Khemiya Mango Grove.
mn94:1.2.comm: Neither monk nor monastery are mentioned elsewhere in early texts.

mn94:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo bārāṇasiṃ anuppatto hoti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
mn94:2.1.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Ghoṭamukha had arrived at Varanasi on some business.
mn94:2.1.comm: This may be the Ghoṭamukha (“Beard-face”) of Kauṭilya’s Arthaśāstra 5.5.11. On the question of when a courtier should know that his king is displeased with him, a series of expert opinions are cited, each one bewilderingly cryptic. Ghoṭamukha says such a king is like a “wet cloth”. The key to these clues is provided in a particular story, which is deliberately unmentioned, presumably because of the delicacy of the subject.

mn94:2.2.pli: Atha kho ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo jaṅghāvihāraṃ anucaṅkamamāno anuvicaramāno yena khemiyambavanaṃ tenupasaṅkami.
mn94:2.2.eng: Then as he was going for a walk he went to the Khemiya Mango Grove.

mn94:2.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā udeno abbhokāse caṅkamati.
mn94:2.3.eng: At that time Venerable Udena was walking mindfully in the open air.

mn94:2.4.pli: Atha kho ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo yenāyasmā udeno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā udenena saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn94:2.4.eng: Ghoṭamukha approached and exchanged greetings with him.

mn94:2.5.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā āyasmantaṃ udenaṃ caṅkamantaṃ anucaṅkamamāno evamāha:

mn94:2.6.eng: “Worthy ascetic, there is no such thing as a principled renunciate life;
mn94:2.6.comm: Ambho samaṇa (“worthy ascetic”) is a unique form of address.

mn94:2.8.pli: Tañca kho bhavantarūpānaṃ vā adassanā, yo vā panettha dhammo”ti.
mn94:2.8.eng: Yet I have not seen honorable ones such as yourself, or a relevant teaching.”

mn94:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā udeno caṅkamā orohitvā vihāraṃ pavisitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
mn94:3.1.eng: When he said this, Udena stepped down from the walking path, entered his dwelling, and sat down on the seat spread out.
mn94:3.1.comm: Udena takes care to ensure the setting is appropriate for a serious discussion.

mn94:3.2.pli: Ghoṭamukhopi kho brāhmaṇo caṅkamā orohitvā vihāraṃ pavisitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
mn94:3.2.eng: Ghoṭamukha also stepped down from the walking path and entered the dwelling, where he stood to one side.

mn94:3.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ kho ghoṭamukhaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ āyasmā udeno etadavoca:

mn94:3.6.pli: “Etadeva kho pana mayaṃ bhoto udenassa āgamayamānā nisīdāma.
mn94:3.6.eng: “I was just waiting for you to sit down.

mn94:3.7.pli: Kathañhi nāma mādiso pubbe animantito āsane nisīditabbaṃ maññeyyā”ti?
mn94:3.7.eng: For how on earth could one such as I presume to sit first without being invited?”

mn94:4.1.pli: Atha kho ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn94:4.1.eng: Then he took a low seat and sat to one side,

mn94:4.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo āyasmantaṃ udenaṃ etadavoca:

mn94:4.3.eng: “Worthy ascetic, there is no such thing as a principled renunciate life;

mn94:4.5.pli: Tañca kho bhavantarūpānaṃ vā adassanā, yo vā panettha dhammo”ti.
mn94:4.5.eng: Yet I have not seen honorable ones such as yourself, or a relevant teaching.”

mn94:4.6.pli: “Sace kho pana me tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, anuññeyyaṃ anujāneyyāsi, paṭikkositabbañca paṭikkoseyyāsi; yassa ca pana me bhāsitassa atthaṃ na jāneyyāsi, mamaṃyeva tattha uttari paṭipuccheyyāsi:
mn94:4.6.eng: “Brahmin, we can discuss this. But only if you grant what should be granted, and reject what should be rejected. And if you ask me the meaning of anything you don’t understand, saying:
mn94:4.6.comm: Ghoṭamukha was unfamiliar with the forms of address, admits he has never seen a mendicant, talks to Udena while he is walking meditation, and does not know when he should sit down. Udena, noticing his awkwardness, makes sure that Ghoṭamukha understands that he can engage in a conversation without impropriety.

mn94:4.7.pli: ‘idaṃ, bho udena, kathaṃ, imassa kvattho’ti? Evaṃ katvā siyā no ettha kathāsallāpo”ti.
mn94:4.7.eng: ‘Sir, why is this? What does that mean?’”

mn94:4.8.pli: “Anuññeyyaṃ khvāhaṃ bhoto udenassa anujānissāmi, paṭikkositabbañca paṭikkosissāmi; yassa ca panāhaṃ bhoto udenassa bhāsitassa atthaṃ na jānissāmi, bhavantaṃyeva tattha udenaṃ uttari paṭipucchissāmi: ‘idaṃ, bho udena, kathaṃ, imassa kvattho’ti? Evaṃ katvā hotu no ettha kathāsallāpo”ti.
mn94:4.8.eng: “Let us discuss this. I will do as you say.”

mn94:5.1.eng: “Brahmin, these four individuals are found in the world.

mn94:5.3.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo attantapo hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn94:5.3.eng: One individual mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.

mn94:5.4.pli: Idha pana, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo parantapo hoti paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn94:5.4.eng: One individual mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.

mn94:5.5.pli: Idha pana, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo attantapo ca hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn94:5.5.eng: One individual mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.

mn94:5.6.pli: Idha pana, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo nevattantapo hoti nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn94:5.6.eng: One individual doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.

mn94:5.7.pli: So anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati.
mn94:5.7.eng: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.

mn94:5.8.pli: Imesaṃ, brāhmaṇa, catunnaṃ puggalānaṃ katamo te puggalo cittaṃ ārādhetī”ti?
mn94:5.8.eng: Which one of these four individuals do you like the sound of?”

mn94:5.9.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, bho udena, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto ayaṃ me puggalo cittaṃ nārādheti;
mn94:5.9.eng: “Sir, I don’t like the sound of the first three individuals.

mn94:5.10.pli: yopāyaṃ, bho udena, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto ayampi me puggalo cittaṃ nārādheti;

mn94:5.11.pli: yopāyaṃ, bho udena, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto ayampi me puggalo cittaṃ nārādheti;

mn94:5.12.pli: yo ca kho ayaṃ, bho udena, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati.

mn94:5.13.eng: I only like the sound of the last individual, who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others.”

mn94:6.1.pli: “Kasmā pana te, brāhmaṇa, ime tayo puggalā cittaṃ nārādhentī”ti?
mn94:6.1.eng: “But why don’t you like the sound of those three individuals?”

mn94:6.2.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, bho udena, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so attānaṃ sukhakāmaṃ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṃ ātāpeti paritāpeti;
mn94:6.2.eng: “Sir, the individual who mortifies themselves does so even though they want to be happy and recoil from pain.

mn94:6.3.pli: iminā me ayaṃ puggalo cittaṃ nārādheti.
mn94:6.3.eng: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that individual.

mn94:6.4.pli: Yopāyaṃ, bho udena, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so paraṃ sukhakāmaṃ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṃ ātāpeti paritāpeti;
mn94:6.4.eng: The individual who mortifies others does so even though others want to be happy and recoil from pain.

mn94:6.5.pli: iminā me ayaṃ puggalo cittaṃ nārādheti.
mn94:6.5.eng: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that individual.

mn94:6.6.pli: Yopāyaṃ, bho udena, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so attānañca parañca sukhakāmaṃ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṃ ātāpeti paritāpeti;
mn94:6.6.eng: The individual who mortifies themselves and others does so even though both themselves and others want to be happy and recoil from pain.

mn94:6.7.pli: iminā me ayaṃ puggalo cittaṃ nārādheti.
mn94:6.7.eng: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that individual.

mn94:6.8.pli: Yo ca kho ayaṃ, bho udena, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati, so attānañca parañca sukhakāmaṃ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṃ neva ātāpeti na paritāpeti;
mn94:6.8.eng: The individual who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others—living without wishes, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine—does not torment themselves or others, both of whom want to be happy and recoil from pain.

mn94:6.9.pli: iminā me ayaṃ puggalo cittaṃ ārādhetī”ti.
mn94:6.9.eng: That’s why I like the sound of that individual.”

mn94:7.1.eng: “There are, brahmin, these two groups of people.

mn94:7.3.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekaccā parisā sārattarattā maṇikuṇḍalesu puttabhariyaṃ pariyesati, dāsidāsaṃ pariyesati, khettavatthuṃ pariyesati, jātarūparajataṃ pariyesati.
mn94:7.3.eng: There’s one group of people who, being obsessed with jeweled earrings, seeks partners and children, male and female bondservants, fields and lands, and gold and currency.

mn94:7.4.pli: Idha pana, brāhmaṇa, ekaccā parisā asārattarattā maṇikuṇḍalesu puttabhariyaṃ pahāya, dāsidāsaṃ pahāya, khettavatthuṃ pahāya, jātarūparajataṃ pahāya, agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā.
mn94:7.4.eng: And there’s another group of people who, not being obsessed with jeweled earrings, has given up partner and children, male and female bondservants, fields and lands, and gold and currency, and goes forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn94:7.5.pli: Svāyaṃ, brāhmaṇa, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn94:7.5.eng: Now, brahmin, that individual who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others—

mn94:7.6.pli: So anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati.

mn94:7.7.pli: Idha katamaṃ tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, puggalaṃ katamāya parisāya bahulaṃ samanupassasi—
mn94:7.7.eng: in which of these two groups of people do you usually find such an individual?”

mn94:7.8.pli: yā cāyaṃ parisā sārattarattā maṇikuṇḍalesu puttabhariyaṃ pariyesati dāsidāsaṃ pariyesati khettavatthuṃ pariyesati jātarūparajataṃ pariyesati, yā cāyaṃ parisā asārattarattā maṇikuṇḍalesu puttabhariyaṃ pahāya dāsidāsaṃ pahāya khettavatthuṃ pahāya jātarūparajataṃ pahāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā”ti?

mn94:7.9.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, bho udena, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati;
mn94:7.9.eng: “I usually find such an individual in

mn94:7.10.pli: imāhaṃ puggalaṃ yāyaṃ parisā asārattarattā maṇikuṇḍalesu puttabhariyaṃ pahāya dāsidāsaṃ pahāya khettavatthuṃ pahāya jātarūparajataṃ pahāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā imissaṃ parisāyaṃ bahulaṃ samanupassāmī”ti.
mn94:7.10.eng: the group that has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

mn94:8.1.pli: “Idāneva kho pana te, brāhmaṇa, bhāsitaṃ: ‘mayaṃ evaṃ ājānāma—
mn94:8.1.eng: “Just now I understood you to say:

mn94:8.2.eng: ‘Worthy ascetic, there is no such thing as a principled renunciate life;

mn94:8.4.pli: Tañca kho bhavantarūpānaṃ vā adassanā, yo vā panettha dhammo’”ti.
mn94:8.4.eng: Yet I have not seen honorable ones such as yourself, or a relevant teaching.”

mn94:8.5.pli: “Addhā mesā, bho udena, sānuggahā vācā bhāsitā.
mn94:8.5.eng: “Well, I obviously had my reasons for saying that, master Udena.
mn94:8.5.comm: The commentary glosses sānuggahā with sakāraṇā, “with reason”.

mn94:8.6.eng: But there is such a thing as a principled renunciate life.

mn94:8.8.pli: Evañca pana maṃ bhavaṃ udeno dhāretu.
mn94:8.8.eng: and that’s how you should remember me.

mn94:8.9.pli: Ye ca me bhotā udenena cattāro puggalā saṅkhittena vuttā vitthārena avibhattā, sādhu me bhavaṃ, udeno ime cattāro puggale vitthārena vibhajatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
mn94:8.9.eng: Now, these four individuals that you’ve spoken of in a brief summary: please explain them to me in detail, out of sympathy.”

mn94:9.1.pli: “Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn94:9.1.eng: “Well then, brahmin, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn94:9.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo āyasmato udenassa paccassosi.

mn94:10.1.eng: “What individual mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves?
mn94:10.1.comm: For details, see notes at MN 12:45.1, MN 27:11.1, and MN 51:8.1.

mn94:10.2.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo acelako hoti muttācāro hatthāpalekhano naehibhaddantiko natiṭṭhabhaddantiko, nābhihaṭaṃ na uddissakataṃ na nimantanaṃ sādiyati.
mn94:10.2.eng: It’s when an individual goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on their behalf, or an invitation for a meal.

mn94:10.3.pli: So na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na eḷakamantaraṃ, na daṇḍamantaraṃ, na musalamantaraṃ, na dvinnaṃ bhuñjamānānaṃ, na gabbhiniyā, na pāyamānāya, na purisantaragatāya, na saṅkittīsu, na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti, na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī, na macchaṃ na maṃsaṃ, na suraṃ na merayaṃ na thusodakaṃ pivati.
mn94:10.3.eng: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.

mn94:10.4.pli: So ekāgāriko vā hoti ekālopiko, dvāgāriko vā hoti dvālopiko …pe… sattāgāriko vā hoti sattālopiko;
mn94:10.4.eng: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.

mn94:10.5.pli: ekissāpi dattiyā yāpeti, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpeti …pe… sattahipi dattīhi yāpeti;
mn94:10.5.eng: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.

mn94:10.6.pli: ekāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti, dvīhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti …pe… sattāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti—iti evarūpaṃ addhamāsikaṃ pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
mn94:10.6.eng: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.

mn94:10.7.pli: So sākabhakkho vā hoti, sāmākabhakkho vā hoti, nīvārabhakkho vā hoti, daddulabhakkho vā hoti, haṭabhakkho vā hoti, kaṇabhakkho vā hoti, ācāmabhakkho vā hoti, piññākabhakkho vā hoti, tiṇabhakkho vā hoti, gomayabhakkho vā hoti, vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī.
mn94:10.7.eng: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.

mn94:10.8.pli: So sāṇānipi dhāreti, masāṇānipi dhāreti, chavadussānipi dhāreti, paṃsukūlānipi dhāreti, tirīṭānipi dhāreti, ajinampi dhāreti, ajinakkhipampi dhāreti, kusacīrampi dhāreti, vākacīrampi dhāreti, phalakacīrampi dhāreti, kesakambalampi dhāreti, vāḷakambalampi dhāreti, ulūkapakkhampi dhāreti;
mn94:10.8.eng: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.

mn94:10.9.eng: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.

mn94:10.10.eng: They constantly stand, turning down seats.

mn94:10.11.eng: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.

mn94:10.12.eng: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.

mn94:10.13.eng: They’re devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including at dusk.

mn94:10.14.pli: iti evarūpaṃ anekavihitaṃ kāyassa ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
mn94:10.14.eng: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.

mn94:10.15.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn94:10.15.eng: This is called an individual who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.

mn94:11.1.pli: Katamo ca, brāhmaṇa, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
mn94:11.1.eng: And what individual mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others?

mn94:11.2.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo orabbhiko hoti sūkariko sākuṇiko māgaviko luddo macchaghātako coro coraghātako goghātako bandhanāgāriko—ye vā panaññepi keci kurūrakammantā.
mn94:11.2.eng: It’s when an individual is a slaughterer of sheep, pigs, poultry, or deer, a hunter or fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher of cattle, a jailer, or has some other cruel livelihood.

mn94:11.3.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn94:11.3.eng: This is called an individual who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.

mn94:12.1.pli: Katamo ca, brāhmaṇa, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
mn94:12.1.eng: And what individual mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others?

mn94:12.2.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo rājā vā hoti khattiyo muddhāvasitto, brāhmaṇo vā mahāsālo.
mn94:12.2.eng: It’s when an individual is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.

mn94:12.3.pli: So puratthimena nagarassa navaṃ santhāgāraṃ kārāpetvā kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kharājinaṃ nivāsetvā sappitelena kāyaṃ abbhañjitvā magavisāṇena piṭṭhiṃ kaṇḍuvamāno navaṃ santhāgāraṃ pavisati saddhiṃ mahesiyā brāhmaṇena ca purohitena.
mn94:12.3.eng: He has a new ceremonial hall built to the east of the citadel. He shaves off his hair and beard, dresses in a rough antelope hide, and smears his body with ghee and oil. Scratching his back with antlers, he enters the hall with his chief queen and the brahmin high priest.

mn94:12.4.pli: So tattha anantarahitāya bhūmiyā haritupalittāya seyyaṃ kappeti.
mn94:12.4.eng: There he lies on the bare ground strewn with grass.

mn94:12.5.pli: Ekissāya gāviyā sarūpavacchāya yaṃ ekasmiṃ thane khīraṃ hoti tena rājā yāpeti, yaṃ dutiyasmiṃ thane khīraṃ hoti tena mahesī yāpeti, yaṃ tatiyasmiṃ thane khīraṃ hoti tena brāhmaṇo purohito yāpeti, yaṃ catutthasmiṃ thane khīraṃ hoti tena aggiṃ juhati, avasesena vacchako yāpeti.
mn94:12.5.eng: The king feeds on the milk from one teat of a cow that has a calf of the same color. The chief queen feeds on the milk from the second teat. The brahmin high priest feeds on the milk from the third teat. The milk from the fourth teat is served to the sacred flame. The calf feeds on the leftovers.

mn94:12.7.pli: ‘ettakā usabhā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatarā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatariyo haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā ajā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā urabbhā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā assā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā rukkhā chijjantu yūpatthāya, ettakā dabbhā lūyantu barihisatthāyā’ti.
mn94:12.7.eng: ‘Slaughter this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, rams, and horses for the sacrifice! Fell this many trees and reap this much grass for the sacrificial equipment!’

mn94:12.8.pli: Yepissa te honti ‘dāsā’ti vā ‘pessā’ti vā ‘kammakarā’ti vā tepi daṇḍatajjitā bhayatajjitā assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni karonti.
mn94:12.8.eng: His bondservants, servants, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.

mn94:12.9.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn94:12.9.eng: This is called an individual who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.

mn94:13.1.pli: Katamo ca, brāhmaṇa, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto;
mn94:13.1.eng: And what individual doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others,

mn94:13.2.pli: so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati?
mn94:13.2.eng: living without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine?

mn94:14.1.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā.
mn94:14.1.eng: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.

mn94:14.2.pli: So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
mn94:14.2.eng: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

mn94:14.3.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
mn94:14.3.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

mn94:15.1.pli: Taṃ dhammaṃ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṃ vā kule paccājāto.
mn94:15.1.eng: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.

mn94:15.2.pli: So taṃ dhammaṃ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṃ paṭilabhati.
mn94:15.2.eng: They gain faith in the Realized One,

mn94:15.3.pli: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:

mn94:15.4.eng: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.

mn94:15.5.pli: Nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ.
mn94:15.5.eng: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.

mn94:15.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan’ti.
mn94:15.6.eng: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

mn94:15.7.pli: So aparena samayena appaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya, appaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya, kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
mn94:15.7.eng: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn94:15.8.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno bhikkhūnaṃ sikkhāsājīvasamāpanno pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
mn94:15.8.eng: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.

mn94:16.1.pli: Adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī. Athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati.
mn94:16.1.eng: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.

mn94:16.2.pli: Abrahmacariyaṃ pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
mn94:16.2.eng: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.

mn94:16.3.pli: Musāvādaṃ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṃvādako lokassa.
mn94:16.3.eng: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.

mn94:16.4.pli: Pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti; ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṃ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṃ akkhātā amūsaṃ bhedāya. Iti bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātā sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā, samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
mn94:16.4.eng: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.

mn94:16.5.pli: Pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti. Yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
mn94:16.5.eng: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.

mn94:16.6.pli: Samphappalāpaṃ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti, kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā kālena sāpadesaṃ pariyantavatiṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ.
mn94:16.6.eng: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.

mn94:16.7.eng: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.

mn94:16.8.eng: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.

mn94:16.9.eng: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .

mn94:16.10.eng: They refrain from attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.

mn94:16.11.eng: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.

mn94:16.12.eng: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,

mn94:16.21.eng: They refrain from running errands and messages;

mn94:16.25.eng: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.

mn94:17.1.pli: So santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena, kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
mn94:17.1.eng: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.

mn94:17.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti sapattabhārova ḍeti;
mn94:17.2.eng: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.

mn94:17.3.pli: evameva bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena, kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
mn94:17.3.eng: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.

mn94:17.4.pli: So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ anavajjasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
mn94:17.4.eng: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.

mn94:18.1.pli: So cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
mn94:18.1.eng: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

mn94:18.2.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ, cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
mn94:18.2.eng: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.

mn94:18.3.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

mn94:18.4.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

mn94:18.5.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

mn94:18.6.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

mn94:18.7.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
mn94:18.7.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

mn94:18.8.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṃ, manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
mn94:18.8.eng: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.

mn94:18.9.pli: So iminā ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ abyāsekasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
mn94:18.9.eng: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.

mn94:19.1.pli: So abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
mn94:19.1.eng: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

mn94:20.1.pli: So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato
mn94:20.1.eng: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,

mn94:20.2.pli: vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ.
mn94:20.2.eng: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.

mn94:21.1.pli: So pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā, ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya, parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
mn94:21.1.eng: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.

mn94:21.2.pli: So abhijjhaṃ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodheti;
mn94:21.2.eng: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.

mn94:21.3.pli: byāpādapadosaṃ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī, byāpādapadosā cittaṃ parisodheti;
mn94:21.3.eng: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.

mn94:21.4.pli: thinamiddhaṃ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṃ parisodheti;
mn94:21.4.eng: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.

mn94:21.5.pli: uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṃ parisodheti;
mn94:21.5.eng: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.

mn94:21.6.pli: vicikicchaṃ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṃ parisodheti.
mn94:21.6.eng: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

mn94:22.1.pli: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
mn94:22.1.eng: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.

mn94:22.2.pli: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn94:22.2.eng: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn94:23.1.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn94:23.1.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn94:24.1.pli: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn94:24.1.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

mn94:25.1.pli: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn94:25.1.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

mn94:26.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn94:26.1.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.

mn94:26.2.pli: So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi, anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto; so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto; so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
mn94:26.2.eng: They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

mn94:27.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṃ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn94:27.1.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.

mn94:27.2.pli: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā …pe… ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā …pe… ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
mn94:27.2.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

mn94:28.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn94:28.1.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.

mn94:28.2.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti;
mn94:28.2.eng: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

mn94:28.3.pli: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn94:28.3.eng: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.

mn94:29.1.pli: Tassa evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati.
mn94:29.1.eng: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

mn94:29.2.eng: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

mn94:29.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
mn94:29.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

mn94:30.1.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn94:30.1.eng: This is called an individual who neither mortifies themselves or others, being committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.

mn94:30.2.pli: So anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharatī”ti.
mn94:30.2.eng: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.”

mn94:31.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo āyasmantaṃ udenaṃ etadavoca:
mn94:31.1.eng: When he had spoken, Ghoṭamukha said to him,

mn94:31.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho udena, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā udenena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
mn94:31.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the worthy Udena has made the teaching clear in many ways.

mn94:31.4.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ udenaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn94:31.4.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Udena, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn94:31.5.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ udeno dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
mn94:31.5.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Udena remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

mn94:32.1.pli: “Mā kho maṃ tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, saraṇaṃ agamāsi.
mn94:32.1.eng: “Brahmin, don’t go for refuge to me.

mn94:32.2.pli: Tameva bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāhi yamahaṃ saraṇaṃ gato”ti.
mn94:32.2.eng: You should go for refuge to that same Blessed One to whom I have gone for refuge.”

mn94:32.3.pli: “Kahaṃ pana, bho udena, etarahi so bhavaṃ gotamo viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho”ti?
mn94:32.3.eng: “But worthy Udena, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”

mn94:32.4.pli: “Parinibbuto kho, brāhmaṇa, etarahi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho”ti.
mn94:32.4.eng: “Brahmin, the Buddha has already become fully quenched.”

mn94:32.5.pli: “Sacepi mayaṃ, bho udena, suṇeyyāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dasasu yojanesu, dasapi mayaṃ yojanāni gaccheyyāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ.
mn94:32.5.eng: “Worthy Udena, if I heard that the Buddha was within ten leagues, or twenty, or even up to a hundred leagues away, I’d go a hundred leagues to see him.

mn94:32.6.pli: Sacepi mayaṃ, bho udena, suṇeyyāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ vīsatiyā yojanesu …

mn94:32.9.pli: paññāsāya yojanesu, paññāsampi mayaṃ yojanāni gaccheyyāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ.

mn94:32.10.pli: Yojanasate cepi mayaṃ, bho udena, suṇeyyāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ, yojanasatampi mayaṃ gaccheyyāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ.

mn94:32.11.pli: Yato ca kho, bho udena, parinibbuto so bhavaṃ gotamo, parinibbutampi mayaṃ taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāma dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn94:32.11.eng: But since the Buddha has become fully quenched, I go for refuge to that fully quenched Buddha, to the teaching, and to the Saṅgha.

mn94:32.12.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ udeno dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gataṃ.
mn94:32.12.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Udena remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.

mn94:33.1.pli: Atthi ca me, bho udena, aṅgarājā devasikaṃ niccabhikkhaṃ dadāti, tato ahaṃ bhoto udenassa ekaṃ niccabhikkhaṃ dadāmī”ti.
mn94:33.1.eng: Worthy Udena, the king of Aṅga gives me a regular daily allowance. I will give you one portion of that.”
mn94:33.1.comm: The mention of the king of Aṅga is unique. Aṅga had been conquered by Bimbisāra long ago and became part of Magadha. There is a faint memory of a time when Rājagaha was a city of Aṅga (Ja 546:36.2), but Aṅga’s glory days were long past. Perhaps “king of Aṅga” was a title of the king of Magadha, or else of a vassal ruler. | Niccabhikkhā at Ja 398:4.1 refers to the daily offering of food to a yakkha, which must be the early meaning. But here and at SN 3.13:4.4 it refers to money.

mn94:33.2.pli: “Kiṃ pana te, brāhmaṇa, aṅgarājā devasikaṃ niccabhikkhaṃ dadātī”ti?
mn94:33.2.eng: “But brahmin, what does the king of Aṅga give you as a regular daily allowance?”

mn94:33.3.comm: A kahāpaṇa is in the ballpark of a US dollar. At AN 10.46 the wages for an honest day’s work start at half a kahāpaṇa, which compares with the poverty line in modern India of 38 rupees/day or 48 US cents. The upper level income is a thousand kahāpaṇas per day, so Ghoṭamukha’s allowance made him a rich man.

mn94:33.4.pli: “Na kho no, brāhmaṇa, kappati jātarūparajataṃ paṭiggahetun”ti.
mn94:33.4.eng: “It’s not proper for us to receive gold and currency.”

mn94:33.5.pli: “Sace taṃ bhoto udenassa na kappati vihāraṃ bhoto udenassa kārāpessāmī”ti.
mn94:33.5.eng: “If that’s not proper, I will have a dwelling built for the worthy Udena.”
mn94:33.5.comm: A vihāra was a “dwelling” in a monastery, not, as in later usage, an entire monastery.

mn94:33.6.pli: “Sace kho me tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, vihāraṃ, kārāpetukāmo, pāṭaliputte saṅghassa upaṭṭhānasālaṃ kārāpehī”ti.
mn94:33.6.eng: “If you want to build me a dwelling, then build an assembly hall for the Saṅgha at Pāṭaliputta.”
mn94:33.6.comm: This reflects the central role of the new capital of Pāṭaliputta after the Buddha died (DN 16:1.28.7). Compare the similar offering at MN 52:16.1.

mn94:33.7.pli: “Imināpāhaṃ bhoto udenassa bhiyyoso mattāya attamano abhiraddho yaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ udeno saṅghe dāne samādapeti.
mn94:33.7.eng: “Now I’m even more delighted and satisfied with the worthy Udena, since he encourages me to give to the Saṅgha.

mn94:33.8.pli: Esāhaṃ, bho udena, etissā ca niccabhikkhāya aparāya ca niccabhikkhāya pāṭaliputte saṅghassa upaṭṭhānasālaṃ kārāpessāmī”ti.
mn94:33.8.eng: So with this allowance and another one I will have an assembly hall built for the Saṅgha at Pāṭaliputta.”

mn94:33.9.pli: Atha kho ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo etissā ca niccabhikkhāya aparāya ca niccabhikkhāya pāṭaliputte saṅghassa upaṭṭhānasālaṃ kārāpesi.
mn94:33.9.eng: And so he had that hall built.

mn94:33.10.eng: And these days it’s called the “Ghoṭamukhī”.
